ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Astrobiology, search for exoplanets, technosignatures, biosignatures, early evolution of life on Earth, the Drake Equation, and basics of astronomy.

A heavily scientific approach to extraterrestrial life, beyond means of science fiction, and how various aspects of STEM, including physics and biology, apply to efforts related to finding ET life. Students were required to base beliefs off of facts rather than biased.

I gained a really great understanding of the factors that affect the probability of extraterrestrial life/intelligence and our current understanding of them. I also got a good basic understanding of planet and star formation, the origins and chemistry of life on Earth, galaxies, and astrobiology.

Throughout this ASTR 030 course taught by Professor Debra Fischer, I learned so much about the universe and its history, and the ongoing search for signs of life on other planets or other solar systems (coming from one of the astronomers who discovered the first multi-planet system of exoplanets)! This course really helped me hone my critical thinking skills, further develop my writing of both essays and peer reviews, and think like a scientist!

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: great instructor, interesting breakout room assignments and discussions, engaging textbook and super fair quizzes


Improvements: none. given the format of having online courses the instructor managed to keep class engagement very high

Strengths: amazing professor with a significant presence in her research field. It was an amazing opportunity to be her student as only a first-year. Her online lectures were detailed and highly informational. Not to mention, the course was designed to promote student learning as opposed to just getting a good grade.

I really appreciated the amount of time given to ask questions and the fact that no prior knowledge of astronomy or advanced math/science was required to understand the course material. However, I didn't feel that we were always given full freedom to discuss the more interesting topics of the course during class time, since our synchronous meetings were heavily structured most of the time. I was also unsure of the exact expectations for our writing assignments a lot of the time, so I think it would be helpful to clarify the style and length of writing expected for the blog posts.

One top Strength is Dr. Fischer and their extraordinary experience, passion, and knowledge (and willingness to share that). In addition, Dr. Fischer has been very thoughtful and mindful on how they organized each week's lectures, resources, and reading materials.
Another Strength is the course material itself. Throughout this course, I learned so much about the universe and its history, and the ongoing search for signs of life on other planets or other solar systems (coming from one of the astronomers who discovered the first multi-planet system of exoplanets)!
Since this course is fascinating, engaging, and challenging, the only suggestion I can think of is having a little fewer non-lecture videos to watch each week (which might allow for deeper discussion).

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Breakout rooms were a little awkward at times, but were sorted out eventually. Discussion format on zoom seemed to work well.
Again, the course was so well-organized, with pre-recorded lecture videos, resources, and other materials which made learning accessible in a virtual learning environment.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes.  Professor Fischer was absolutely incredible; her knowledge and passion for the subject made this class an amazing experience.

Absolutely. The search for extraterrestrial life is a foundational question humans have wondered for years. You are taught by a leading exoplanet researcher who cares deeply about the subject. The material is super interesting and the workload is very manageable.
Yes! Great professor, great topic
Yes I would recommended this course to another student. The class was very interesting and informative, without being overwhelming with work.

Yes! Professor Fischer did such an amazing job focusing on both her STEM and non STEM major students. Its very accessible to all. Not to mention, being the student of a highly regarded researcher was an amazing opportunity.

I would recommend it if you're very interested in astronomy and the possibility of extraterrestrial life, because it does explore those topics thoroughly and give a good understanding of them. The course does have a relatively heavy workload, with weekly recorded lectures, synchronous seminar meetings, weekly readings, quizzes, blog posts (essays), and problem sets, so you should go into the course aware of this. It's a solid science credit that genuinely taught me a lot about astronomy without too much hard science, and there is a lot of writing instead of much math.

Definitely! If you want to understand more about the universe and its history, and the ongoing search for signs of life on other planets or other solar systems (while also improving your writing and learning to think like a scientist), then I'd take this course!

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: In addition to the virtual seminar, there were recorded lectures to watch before each section and occasionally we would recap a lecture in the discussion.
Some online lectures were recorded and we were required to watch them before class.
Virtual seminar with recorded lectures
prerecorded lectures
A pre-recorded lecture video to be watched before each class, and a live virtual class as well
